description:
Leonard Alvin Johnson, Jr., of Springfield, died Dec. 23, 2025.
Leonard was born March 30, 1945, in Springfield to Leonard A. Johnson, Sr., and Bertha (Gorth) Johnson.
After graduation from St. Agnes High School in 1963, he joined the Marine Reserves, then returned and began a career in electronic circuit board manufacturing.
He then became an owner of a manufacturing plant in California.
Survivors include his son, Richard (Regina) of Strafford; grandsons Reese Johnson, Zachary Johnson, Gabriel Johnson and Christopher Johnson, all of Strafford; and cousins Kenneth Johnson and Jason Johnson of Springfield and Glenda Kemple of Dallas, Texas.
text:
Leonard Alvin Johnson, Jr., of Springfield, died Dec. 23, 2025. He was 80 years old.

Leonard was born March 30, 1945, in Springfield to Leonard A. Johnson, Sr., and Bertha (Gorth) Johnson. After graduation from St. Agnes High School in 1963, he joined the Marine Reserves, then returned and began a career in electronic circuit board manufacturing.

He started at the Springfield plant of Litton Systems and gained expertise in quality control that led to positions at other plants in New Jersey, Florida and California. He then became an owner of a manufacturing plant in California. After selling it, he became a broker, matching circuit board manufacturers with customers needing electronic components.

He continued to remotely operate his brokerage, Inner-Link Systems, over the internet after moving back to Springfield in the early 2000s. He remained here after retiring about 2010. He had been a resident of Glendale Gardens Nursing Home in recent years.

Leonard had a lifelong interest in cars and trucks, especially Ford products. He had owned performance vehicles and custom hotrods, and enjoyed participating in car shows and gatherings. He also enjoyed fishing on Ozarks lakes.

In addition to his parents and one sister, Katherine, Leonard was preceded in death by his wife, Charlotte.

Survivors include his son, Richard (Regina) of Strafford; grandsons Reese Johnson, Zachary Johnson, Gabriel Johnson and Christopher Johnson, all of Strafford; and cousins Kenneth Johnson and Jason Johnson of Springfield and Glenda Kemple of Dallas, Texas.

A funeral service will be held Wednesday, December 31, 2025 at 11:00 AM at Gorman-Scharpf Funeral Home, with burial later in Clear Creek Cemetery.

name: Walmart
title: Shopper slams Walmart over concerning product change: 'Heading in the wrong direction'
description:
A Redditor shared a photo in the r/Anticonsumption subreddit showing a packaging change at Walmart.
The retail giant seems to be swapping out its recyclable cardboard pasta boxes for plastic bags.
"Walmart is slowly swapping from cardboard to plastic packaging with their pasta," the Redditor captions the image that shows the two packaging options side by side.
Recyclable cardboard is often made from post-consumer materials, and it has a high recyclable success rate of 70%.
And while some single-use plastic bags can be recycled, not all can.
text:
A Redditor shared a photo in the r/Anticonsumption subreddit showing a packaging change at Walmart. The retail giant seems to be swapping out its recyclable cardboard pasta boxes for plastic bags.

"Walmart is slowly swapping from cardboard to plastic packaging with their pasta," the Redditor captions the image that shows the two packaging options side by side.

While switching from cardboard to single-use plastic may make the packaging lighter, it's still not ideal for the planet for a few reasons.

First, cardboard boxes are fully recyclable, and most municipalities process cardboard in their recycling programs. Recyclable cardboard is often made from post-consumer materials, and it has a high recyclable success rate of 70%.

Second, Walmart recently announced a shift toward electric trucks for some deliveries, helping to reduce its carbon footprint and decrease its production of carbon pollution. Shipping fully-recyclable containers on pollution-free trucks is better for the planet virtually 100% of the time.

Using plastic means dirty energy sources are still involved in the product, since plastic is a byproduct of dirty energy. And while some single-use plastic bags can be recycled, not all can. These flimsy bags often tear, making them not an ideal reuse candidate. Plastic is also a leading ocean polluter, poisoning wildlife and exacerbating the overheating of our planet.

Redditors were quick to blast the retail giant's decision. "[Y]ou would hope the swap would be the other way," wrote one user.

"We are heading in the wrong direction," wrote another user.

One Redditor shared some insight as to why Walmart may have made the shift. "I work in packaging," they wrote. "There have been intermittent paper shortages since COVID. It's getting a little better now, but I've seen a lot of brands go from paper to cheap overseas plastic, [as] opposed to paying a few cents more per unit to get it made domestically with paper."

name: S&P Global
title: Investors might prevent fossil fuel expansion - The Energy Mix
description:
“but a dimming outlook for oil prices next year means the cash shortfall is apt to continue over the longer term,” while investors’ expectations for immediate returns continue.
Consistent with other recent analysis, a senior IEA official said it was possible that China’s oil demand had already peaked.
And crude oil prices fell 11% between early October and mid-November.
Consistent with other recent analysis, a senior IEA official said it was possible that China’s oil demand had already peaked.
Increased U.S. production doesn’t fundamentally change the picture, but it does increase the risk to Canada.”
text:
This story is part of a selection of our top news from 2025 that we’re republishing during the holiday break. We’ll be back to our regular schedule in the new year.

With Donald Trump pledging a “Drill, Baby, Drill” agenda for fossil fuels that would pour an estimated four billion tonnes of additional climate pollution into the atmosphere, nervous private investors emerged early this year as a force that could impede the oil and gas industry from keeping Trump’s promise.

Their demands for bigger, faster returns on their fossil investments, coupled with heightened fear of declining oil demand and surging clean energy alternatives, had independent analysts and even some industry insiders concluding there’s no sudden oil boom on the horizon.

It isn’t that the industry didn’t want to ramp up production after the U.S. presidency changed hands Jan. 20. It’s that cautious investors might prevent them from doing that.

The U.S. fossil fuel industry spent US$219 million to elect the country’s next government, Yale Climate Connections reports, most of it on Republican campaigns. That was after Trump invited about 20 oil and gas executives to his Mar-a-Lago estate in April to present what one independent journalist called a “breathtakingly corrupt proposal: If they raised a billion dollars to help him retake the White House, he would roll back any policy they didn’t like when he took office.”

In the end, the election result was a bargain at one-fifth the price Trump asked the industry to pay. Not long after the dust settled on last fall’s presidential vote, the American Energy Alliance (AEA) declared itself pleased with Trump’s cabinet nominations.

“Throughout his campaign, President Trump expressed his unwavering commitment to American [fossil] energy, and his selections show how serious he is about unlocking our country’s resource potential,” AEA President Thomas Pyle said in a Nov. 26 statement. “He has chosen strong candidates to comprise his energy team,” all of whom “share a vision for energy dominance and economic growth.”

Those plans could pour an extra four billion tonnes of greenhouse gas emissions into the atmosphere by 2030, Carbon Brief concluded last March.

Funnelling Cash Out of Production

But the industry’s behaviour is not matching up with its rhetoric. As far back as March 2023, with analysts predicting (as it turned out, over-predicting) $100-per-barrel oil and U.S. President Joe Biden urging companies to increase production, industry leaders were directing their record profits to investor dividends and share buybacks, diverting funds that would previously have been devoted to seeking out and developing new oilfields.

With shareholders basking in a $128-billion financial windfall, “oil executives who in years past were rewarded for investing in gigantic, long-term energy projects are now under the gun to funnel cash to investors who are increasingly convinced that the sunset of the fossil-fuel era is nigh,” Bloomberg Green reported at the time.

“At the heart of the divergence is growing concern among investors that demand for fossil fuels will peak as soon as 2030, obviating the need for multi-billion-dollar megaprojects that take decades to yield full returns,” the news story stated. “In other words, oil refineries and natural-gas fired power plants—along with the wells that feed them—risk becoming so-called stranded assets if and when they are displaced by electric cars and battery farms.”

Projections that oil consumption will peak this decade may have begun with the IEA, but the chorus of agreement now includes private energy analytics firms like Wood Mackenzie and Rystad Energy, as well as oil giants like BP and Exxon.

Against that backdrop, the June 2024 World Energy Investment report by the International Energy Agency (IEA) traced the decline in capital expenditures back nearly a decade. It said global investment in “upstream” oil exploration and extraction activity was set to fall to its lowest level since 2017, with state-owned oil corporations in the Middle East and Asia accounting for a far larger share of the total and the major private oil companies cutting investment by about one-quarter.

Among the world’s 30 biggest upstream oil producers, dividends and stock buybacks exceeded [pdf] capital spending in 2022 and 2023, with investment in exploration and extraction falling from more than 75% in 2015 to less than 50% of the total.

The same IEA report showed the world investing nearly twice as much in clean energy as it does in fossil fuels.

Borrow Billions, Hand It All Over to Investors

Now, some of the world’s biggest fossil producers are facing down a new layer of risk: with oil demand collapsing, prices staying stubbornly low, and investors still laser focused on short-term returns, four of the world’s five oil “supermajors” saw fit to borrow $15 billion to fund share buybacks between July and September, Bloomberg reported in late October.

With their quarterly profits at their lowest since 2021, down by half from record highs in 2022 and by 12% from the previous quarter, analysts said colossal fossils ExxonMobil, Chevron, TotalÉnergies, and BP wouldn’t have enough cash on hand to cover the dividends and share buybacks their investors were demanding. While Exxon and Chevron had “plenty of room to borrow to fund buybacks,” Bloomberg wrote, “the European majors have higher debt levels, allowing less room to manoeuvre,” with BP posting the worst financial performance based on its ratio of debt to capital assets.

“Borrowing to buy back shares isn’t uncommon in the oil business,” Bloomberg explained. “but a dimming outlook for oil prices next year means the cash shortfall is apt to continue over the longer term,” while investors’ expectations for immediate returns continue.

Another Day, Another Debt

Going deeper into debt to hand money over to shareholders “could be a good use of cash while companies have reasonably strong balance sheets,” Kim Fustier, head of European oil and gas equity research at HSBC Plc, told the news agency. “The question is, ‘How sustainable will it be?’”

“While it is common for companies to borrow to maintain dividends during lean periods on the premise of a cyclical recovery, it is quite another thing to do the same when the decline is structural,” agreed Guy Prince, a senior analyst on Carbon Tracker’s oil, gas and mining team, in a December 2023 analysis tracking the financial decline of 40 different petrostates—particularly Saudi Arabia.

“Falling oil demand will have varying impacts on companies,” he wrote. “However, for Saudi Aramco, with its self-imposed production targets (to shore up prices) and fixed dividend payments to the Saudi government to fund its fiscal spend (they need $80 a barrel), it is particularly painful.”

Over a nine-month span in 2024, Aramco’s financial position “has moved from net cash of $27.4 billion to net debt of $8.9 billion,” Bloomberg energy and commodities columnist Javier Blas wrote on social media. “That means in 2024 Aramco has spent ~$130 million daily that it didn’t have.”

The overall financial picture points to a rather less aggressive picture of the next four years of fossil fuel development than Trump’s and the industry’s chatter about making “American Energy Great Again”, just months after U.S. crude production set an all-time record under Biden.

Low Oil Prices Mean Falling Profits

It’ll be that much harder for Big Oil to deliver on all the big talk as long as it’s caught between two converging trends: jittery investors and relatively low prices driven by faltering demand for oil.

“Oil consumption in China—the powerhouse of world markets for the past two decades—has contracted for six straight months through September, and will grow this year at just 10% of the rate seen in 2023,” Bloomberg reported in mid-November, citing IEA analysis. Consistent with other recent analysis, a senior IEA official said it was possible that China’s oil demand had already peaked.

The result: global oil consumption will still rise this year, but at less than half the rate of 2023. And crude oil prices fell 11% between early October and mid-November.

“It’s not just the economy and the shift, the slowdown in the construction sector,” the agency’s head of oil industry and markets, Toril Bosoni, told Bloomberg TV. “It’s the transition to electric vehicles, high speed rail, and gas in trucking that is undermining Chinese oil demand growth.”

That shaky picture of future demand had the U.S. Energy Information Administration rolling back its 2025 price projection for West Texas Intermediate crude oil—from an estimate of $79.63 per barrel last September to $73.13 in October and $69.12 in December. Falling prices will only erode profits and available funds that companies are already redirecting from exploration and production to shareholder returns.

Those same price dynamics had the Organization for Petroleum Exporting Countries and its petrostate allies (OPEC+) balancing an “unpalatable choice” between the mounting financial pain of restraining production and the risk that bringing new oil supplies online would just drive down prices farther and faster, Bloomberg wrote in late November. By mid-December, the cartel was “gradually conceding defeat”, the news agency said, slashing its estimates of future demand growth and bringing them closer to the IEA’s—which Saudi Energy Minister Abdulaziz bin Salman had previously dismissed as “La La Land” for its recent emphasis on net-zero scenarios.

California-based Chevron also announced a $2-billion capital expenditure cut, its first since the COVID-19 pandemic, in early December, a decision the Financial Times placed in counterpoint to Trump’s “energy dominance” agenda. That left Exxon as a major outlier, with announced plans to increase production by nearly one-fifth and continue boosting capital spending through the end of this decade.

Oil Producers Tap the Brakes

But even Exxon is throwing cold water on Trump’s pledge to drill everything, everywhere, all at once.

“I think a radical change is unlikely because the vast majority, if not everybody, is primarily focused on the economics of what they’re doing,” the company’s Upstream President Liam Mallon told a conference audience in late November. If Trump follows through on plans to open up public lands in the U.S. to oil and gas production, “You would be able to drill more, assuming you have the quality and met your economic threshold,” he added. “But I don’t think we’re going to see anybody in the ‘Drill, baby, drill!’ mode. I really don’t.”

“Maybe he has a magic recipe to push them to drill like mad,” added TotalÉnergies CEO Patrick Pouyanne. But with companies committed to returning cash to shareholders, “it’s not only decisions by politicians” that will determine how much oil the U.S. produces.

The skepticism extended beyond the oil and gas executive suite.

“There is a recent media narrative that the second Trump administration will lead to a surge in U.S. oil production, with producers eager to drill and produce more when unincumbered [sic] by perceived Biden-era bureaucracy,” wrote Standard Chartered Bank Energy Analyst Emily Ashford in a post-election analysis. But U.S. oil production “has changed significantly since Trump first took office in 2017, and there are substantial barriers to rapid production increases within the time frame of a presidential term.”

Another take on that history is that, with U.S. production now at record levels, Trump can’t do much more because Biden has already given the industry pretty much everything it wants.

There are certainly steps Trump may try to take to boost the industry. But notwithstanding his campaign trail claims that U.S. oil production would have been “four, five times” higher if he had stayed in the White House after losing the 2020 election, Politico says oil companies “are already signaling they will pull back on drilling next year as crude oil prices sag.” They’re also “wary that Trump’s threatened tariffs will worsen trade tensions, driving up their costs and risking closing off foreign markets for their energy exports.”

Hazards Ahead for Canadian Oil

The global trends have Canadian politicians and analysts fretting that “three years of roaring oil prices” are coming to an end. “Both investors and companies have become used to these [high] prices,” Raoul LeBlanc vice-president at S&P Global Commodity Insights, told CBC in early November. “Whereas five years ago—let’s say 2017, 2018, and 2019—prices at $62 [a barrel] would have seemed fantastic, they don’t seem fantastic now.”

Echoing the analysis in the U.S., LeBlanc said the Canadian industry will still be expected to deliver strong returns to investors, even if it means cutting back on plans to increase production.

Around the same time, the Globe and Mail reports, University of Calgary economist Trevor Tombe said Alberta will lose C$4.5 billion in its next fiscal year if oil prices stay at their present level, making future provincial deficits “a near certainty.”

The combination of rising population and falling oil prices had Premier Danielle Smith acknowledging her government might not be able to balance its budget after projecting a $2.6-billion surplus for 2025-26—and previously promising a personal income tax cut that would reduce provincial revenue by $1.4 billion.

“It is a serious problem,” she told media. “We have a number of different pressures coming our way. And we have to be honest with people about what we’re facing.”

Hadrian Mertins-Kirkwood, senior climate policy researcher at the Canadian Centre for Policy Alternatives, said the Alberta oil sands could be uniquely vulnerable as global oil demand weakens.

“There is a real and growing possibility that demand for Canadian oil exports will fall sooner and faster than anticipated,” he wrote in a November 2024 special edition of CCPA’s ShiftStorm e-newsletter, “not only because of falling demand for oil in general, but specifically because the oil sands are among the costliest and most emissions intensive sources of oil in the world.”

Mertins-Kirkwood agreed with other analysts that Trump isn’t likely to deliver the dramatic production increase he’s been touting.

“You can claim ‘Drill, baby, drill!’ all you want, but that doesn’t change the long-term demand picture, which the oil companies are well aware of,” he told The Energy Mix in an email. “I wouldn’t be surprised to see an increase in new U.S. oil and gas investment under Trump, but it won’t be a dramatic change from business-as-usual for the industry.”

Either way, Mertins-Kirkwood sees serious jeopardy ahead for Alberta and Canada.

“Canada’s fossil fuel industry has assets currently worth half a trillion dollars, and those companies also hold hundreds of billions of dollars in debt. Any decline in production ahead of plan introduces a huge risk of stranded assets,” he wrote.

Even if countries fall short of their declared 2050 deadline to hit net-zero emissions, “We’re going to see a big risk of stranded assets in Canada within 20 years. Increased U.S. production doesn’t fundamentally change the picture, but it does increase the risk to Canada.”

name: OpenAI
title: 8 of the Biggest (and Most Interesting) Deals of 2025 - Inc. Magazine
description:
When it came to investments, mergers and acquisitions, 2025 was a particularly busy year.
More importantly, perhaps, it was also a year with some very interesting deals.
The tech sector was especially busy with deal-making this year as companies looked to find a way to leverage the AI boom.
News of the agreement sent Oracle stock up 43 percent when it was announced.
Go inside one interesting founder-led company each day to find out how its strategy works, and what risk factors it faces.
text:
When it came to investments, mergers and acquisitions, 2025 was a particularly busy year. More importantly, perhaps, it was also a year with some very interesting deals.

In the first nine months of 2025, global M&A activity was up 10 percent over what it was in the same period in 2024, despite the headwinds of geopolitical tensions and tariff policies that seemed to change every few weeks. The tech sector was especially busy with deal-making this year as companies looked to find a way to leverage the AI boom.

But some activity stood out from the rest. Here’s a look at the deals that made this year so unique.

Intel and the U.S. government

The Trump Administration surprised both the tech world and Wall Street in August, announcing that the federal government was taking a 10 percent stake in the chipmaker. (That was especially astonishing, as Trump had, just weeks before, strongly criticized Intel’s CEO on social media, saying he was “highly CONFLICTED and must resign.”)

Featured Video

An Inc.com Featured Presentation

The government picked up 433.3 million shares of non-voting stock priced at $20.47 apiece, making it one of the company’s largest shareholders. The deal has already paid off, with the government’s stake now worth nearly $9 billion more than it paid for the stock.

Stargate

OpenAI, SoftBank and Oracle, in January, jointly announced a massive AI data center project called “Stargate,” in which the companies plan to invest up to $500 billion over the coming years to develop AI infrastructure in the U.S.

Stargate, the companies said, will create 100,000 jobs. Plans were announced in September for five new AI data centers. Stargate will be set up as a separate company, which OpenAI said in a social media post “will not only support the re-industrialization of the United States but also provide a strategic capability to protect the national security of America and its allies.”

OpenAI and Oracle

In September, OpenAI signed a contract with Oracle to purchase $300 billion in computing power over the next five years, one of the largest cloud contracts ever. The contact will begin in 2027, but it did draw some concern from some analysts, who noted the value of the deal was much greater than OpenAI’s current revenue and Oracle will need to take on substantial debt to build out the hardware and infrastructure for the project. News of the agreement sent Oracle stock up 43 percent when it was announced. (It has since lost all of those gains.)

Pepsi and Poppi

Founded in 2020, Poppi started as an experiment in Allison Ellsworth’s kitchen, an attempt to make gut-healthy drinks that tasted good. The probiotic soda quickly grew into a popular, nationally recognized brand during the pandemic, landing Poppi at No. 148 on this year’s Inc. 5000 list, with a three-year growth rate of 2,638 percent. In May, Ellsworth and her husband Stephen, who is also a co-founder, sold the company to Pepsi for $1.95 billion.

Prada and Versace

The news in April that Prada would buy Versace for $1.51 billion was the ending to a very long story. Prada began chasing the luxury fashion house during the pandemic, but the parties couldn’t make the deal work. When Versace parent Capri’s sale to Tapestry was scuttled due to antitrust concerns, Prada tried again and was able to negotiate a price that was lower than the $2 billion Capri paid for the brand in 2018. The acquisition closed earlier this month.

Dick’s Sporting Goods and Foot Locker

Dick’s Sporting Goods had a strong 2025, raising its full-year sales growth guidance last month to a range of 3.5 to 4 percent up from 2 to 3.5 percent previously. Its acquisition of struggling competitor Foot Locker in May for $2.4 billion gave it a competitive advantage in the Nike sneaker market as well as access to international markets and a wider customer base. Foot Locker will continue to operate as a standalone business, though Dick’s does plan to close an undisclosed number of stores to protect the company’s profits.

Sycamore Partners and Walgreens Boots Alliance

Private equity firm Sycamore’s $10 billion purchase of the pharmaceutical chain in March ended almost a century of Walgreens being a publicly traded company. Walgreens, at one point in time, boasted a market cap of nearly $100 billion, but changes to the healthcare industry, acquisitions of rivals and reduced margins on drug sales shrank that number precipitously. Sycamore has a history of buying distressed companies, with other holdings including Staples, Nine West and Talbots.

Keurig Dr Pepper and JDE Peets

Keurig Dr Pepper’s U.S. coffee business needed some help, so it made an $18 billion bet in August that the Dutch coffee and tea company could boost earnings. Keurig Dr Pepper owns Green Mountain Coffee (as well as Dr Pepper, 7Up and Snapple), which has seen sales decline in recent years. The deal is expected to close in the first half of 2026, after which Keurig Dr Pepper will split its coffee and other beverage units into two separate companies, both of which will remain listed on U.S. stock exchanges.

name: OpenAI
title: OpenAI Is Hiring Head of Preparedness, Amid AI Cyberattack Fears | PCMag
description:
If you’re interested in a high-stress, high-compensation role, where you get to battle the emerging threat of frontier-grade AI systems being used for malicious cyberattacks, OpenAI might have the job for you.
The ChatGPT firm has announced it’s hiring a Head of Preparedness.
Whoever lands the new role will be expected to keep up with evolving AI risks, and oversee the company's "preparedness framework as new risks, capabilities, or external expectations emerge."
Reports about burnout at the AI firm have been building for some time, as per reports from publications like Wired.
Disclosure: Ziff Davis, PCMag's parent company, filed a lawsuit against OpenAI in April 2025, alleging it infringed Ziff Davis copyrights in training and operating its AI systems.
text:
If you’re interested in a high-stress, high-compensation role, where you get to battle the emerging threat of frontier-grade AI systems being used for malicious cyberattacks, OpenAI might have the job for you.

The ChatGPT firm has announced it’s hiring a Head of Preparedness. In a post on X, CEO Sam Altman said the position would work on mitigating the growing threat of AI being used aggressively by bad actors in the world of cybersecurity. He claimed we are now “seeing models get so good at computer security they are beginning to find critical vulnerabilities.”

The CEO’s statements about LLMs posing growing risks to cyberdefenders are backed up by other firms in the industry. Last month, OpenAI rival Anthropic posted a report about how a Chinese state-sponsored group manipulated its Claude Code tool into attempting infiltration of “roughly thirty global targets,” including large tech companies, financial institutions, chemical manufacturers, and government agencies, “without substantial human intervention.”

Altman called for candidates who “want to help the world figure out how to enable cybersecurity defenders with cutting-edge capabilities” while still “ensuring attackers can't use them for harm.” According to the job spec, other major risk areas the successful candidate is set to work on include “biosecurity.” In this context, biosecurity could mean advanced AI systems being used to design bioweapons, a risk more than 100 scientists from universities and organizations across the planet have warned about.

Whoever lands the new role will be expected to keep up with evolving AI risks, and oversee the company's "preparedness framework as new risks, capabilities, or external expectations emerge."

Though the compensation package on offer looks generous—north of $500k plus equity—it doesn’t look like a gig for the faint of heart. Altman said it is set to be “a stressful job” that will see the successful candidate “jump into the deep end pretty much immediately.”

There’s a good chance the CEO isn’t exaggerating when it comes to the position’s stress levels. Reports about burnout at the AI firm have been building for some time, as per reports from publications like Wired. Former technical team executives like Calvin French-Owen have posted first-hand accounts of a secretive, high-pressure environment, with a heavy emphasis on Twitter "vibes", alongside anecdotal reports of 12-hour days being plentiful on social media.

Disclosure: Ziff Davis, PCMag's parent company, filed a lawsuit against OpenAI in April 2025, alleging it infringed Ziff Davis copyrights in training and operating its AI systems.

name: J&J
title: After six straight losses and a players-only meeting, where do the Hawks go from here?
description:
This home losing streak began with two losses to Chicago, including one where the Hawks gave up a staggering 152 points.
One way to prove you’re beyond playing your annual elimination game against the Bulls in April is to beat them in December.
A home game against New Orleans on Jan. 7 might be the only one in which the Hawks are favored.
He finally staggered Young and Johnson to keep one on the court at all times, avoiding some of the bench unit disasters that have plagued the Hawks in previous losses.
It also offers more rest: Saturday was the Hawks’ league-leading 33rd game and they only have four back-to-backs after Jan. 3.
text:
ATLANTA — The irony was hard to miss: The visiting coach in Atlanta Saturday night was New York’s Mike Brown, who was fired by Sacramento exactly one year ago to the day after his team lost a fifth consecutive home game.

Welp.

Quin Snyder’s seat hasn’t been rumored to be hot, but the Hawks lost their fifth straight home game and sixth straight overall on Saturday, 128-125 to the Knicks, as Nickeil Alexander-Walkers’s 3-point attempt rattled out just before the buzzer. That this losing streak has coincided with the return of Trae Young for the last four games — something that theoretically should make the Hawks significantly better — only adds to the local angst about this team.

Instead of moving up in the East hierarchy, as many expected at the start of the season, Atlanta is stuck in extremely familiar territory: jousting with the Heat and Bulls for positioning in the play-in tournament. This home losing streak began with two losses to Chicago, including one where the Hawks gave up a staggering 152 points. One way to prove you’re beyond playing your annual elimination game against the Bulls in April is to beat them in December.

Atlanta is now 15-18, in tenth place in the East, and the upcoming schedule offers few reprieves with games against the Thunder, Wolves and Knicks again. Eight of the next 10 games are on the road; eight of the next nine are against teams with winning records. A home game against New Orleans on Jan. 7 might be the only one in which the Hawks are favored. Yikes.

The Hawks haven’t always played badly in this stretch; they lost at the buzzer to a good Knicks team and were beaten by a phantom call in the second loss to the Bulls. The underlying stats still say they’re more an average team than a bad one — 16th in offense, 17th in defense, 18th in Net Rating.

But they also face-planted in a winnable, rested game against Miami and played no defense in the first loss to the Bulls. And more importantly, the expectations were for more this year after acquiring Kristaps Porziņģis and Nickeil Alexander-Walker in the offseason.

That said, the feeling internally after Saturday’s game was slightly different from what you might expect; Atlanta took encouragement after rallying from an 18-point deficit to briefly take the lead in the fourth quarter, coming on the heels of a team meeting after the moribund loss to Miami the night before.

“We had a real sit-down with the whole crew and said we need to be better,” said Alexander-Walker, “and I think you can feel it in the game, in the stretch where we were able to kind of stop the bleeding, we fought.”

“I was proud of how we competed,” said Snyder. “You would like to get a win because that’s affirming of how you played, but we did the things we need to do to be successful.”

“We told each other we need to be serious,” said Jalen Johnson. “A lot of guys spoke. I think it was a good sign.”

Snyder may have also finally landed on something that works rotationally after experimenting, mostly unsuccessfully, with his bench units for much of the year. He finally staggered Young and Johnson to keep one on the court at all times, avoiding some of the bench unit disasters that have plagued the Hawks in previous losses. Guards Keaton Wallace and Luke Kennard, who featured in some of the worst-performing units and have a minus-11.5 per 100 net rating as a two-man unit, combined for just eight total minutes over the last two nights.

“We had more urgency; we were more dialed in,” said Onyeka Okongwu of the Hawks’ rally. The 6-foot-8 center had 31 points and 14 rebounds despite giving up many inches.

“We need to challenge ourselves to play a whole game and not go through lapses.”

Alas, the Hawks face a size deficit every night without the 7-3 Porziņģis, whose POTS syndrome has him sidelined; he has only played 13 games this year. That and a season-ending injury to third center N’Faly Dante have left the Hawks bereft of size, an especially noticeable deficit against New York’s Karl-Anthony Towns and Mitchell Robinson. Atlanta is 27th in Rebound Rate, ahead of only Milwaukee, Sacramento and Washington, and their nightly Ls in the possession battle have made for a burdensome math problem.

The flip side of the Hawks’ tough upcoming schedule is that it gets Charmin soft starting in February, with a surfeit of Charlottes and Washingtons on the docket and only 10 road games after the All-Star break. It also offers more rest: Saturday was the Hawks’ league-leading 33rd game and they only have four back-to-backs after Jan. 3. But they may be down so bad by then that it won’t matter.

The tough schedule also raises the stakes for what might be next for this franchise, whether at the trade deadline or in the offseason. Atlanta has to make its deadline decisions without the benefit of seeing how many wins its soft late schedule might yield. Meanwhile, Young’s return has yet to impact the bottom line while perhaps detracting some from the electric Johnson, especially late in games. Young’s $49 million player option looms as a major hinge point for the offseason.

Both Johnson and Young have also been guilty of glaring defensive gaffes. Here’s Young standing at the free-throw line while Miami runs out for a lay-up in Friday’s fourth quarter:

Meanwhile, when Snyder lamented after the Miami game that the Hawks would stop a driver and then get beat on a back cut, it wasn’t hard to identify what play was on his mind. Here’s Johnson falling asleep on the weak side, something that’s happened way too often this year in what has otherwise been an All-Star-caliber campaign:

Porziņģis, of course, is another giant question mark. He’s an All-Star-caliber weapon when available, but on an expiring $31 million deal that could end up being an important trade chip at the deadline.

Atlanta still owes its first-round pick this year to San Antonio from the Dejounte Murray trade, so they have no incentive for a fire sale. But if this team can’t escape the gravitational field of the play-in tournament for a fifth consecutive season, it raises an important question for the front office as it tries to build around a young core, a likely high lottery pick from New Orleans or Milwaukee and … it remains to be seen what else.

name: Philips
title: Defense becomes Netherlands' largest employer, outpacing police - NL Times
description:
In the previous de Volkskrant survey, defense and the police were roughly equal at about 62,000 full-time jobs each.
“The armed forces face the task of strengthening themselves at high speed,” a Defense Ministry spokesperson said.
Pension administrator APG will cut 1,000 jobs, partly because artificial intelligence is taking over tasks in the financial sector.
A.S. Watson employs more than 16,000 full-time equivalents, while Total Care of CSU in Uden has more than 22,000.
ASML stands out as the fastest-growing employer, with more than 21,000 full-time jobs in the Netherlands, up more than 76 percent in five years.
text:
Defense has become by far the largest employer in the Netherlands, overtaking the police after rapid expansion driven by geopolitical tensions following Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, according to new research by de Volkskrant. At the same time, the civil service has grown sharply, and chipmaker ASML has emerged as the fastest-growing private employer.

Defense employed 74,333 full-time equivalent positions at the end of last year, nearly 20 percent more than five years earlier. In the previous de Volkskrant survey, defense and the police were roughly equal at about 62,000 full-time jobs each. Police staffing has since risen by 5.5 percent to 64,618.

“The armed forces face the task of strengthening themselves at high speed,” a Defense Ministry spokesperson said. “It is therefore positive to see that there is a lot of interest in a job with defense.”

Ahold Delhaize ranks third overall and is the largest private employer, with about 97,000 workers in the Netherlands, equivalent to roughly 38,000 full-time jobs. That is 6,000 more than five years ago. The Ministry of Justice and Security follows with nearly 37,000 full-time positions, while Rabobank has about 31,000, a decline of roughly a quarter over five years.

Employment at ING and ABN Amro remained stable recently due to hiring for anti-money-laundering controls, but cuts are coming. ABN Amro has announced 5,200 job losses, nearly a quarter of its workforce. Pension administrator APG will cut 1,000 jobs, partly because artificial intelligence is taking over tasks in the financial sector.

The civil service expanded strongly, with central government employment rising from more than 125,000 full-time jobs in 2020 to over 157,000 last year. The Tax and Customs Administration employs more than 28,000 full-time workers, UWV nearly 20,000, and the Ministry of Infrastructure and Water Management more than 16,000.

Industry employment continued to shrink at companies such as VDL and Philips, both below 9,000 full-time jobs, and at Tata Steel, which dropped below 10,000. Retail and services remain labor-intensive. A.S. Watson employs more than 16,000 full-time equivalents, while Total Care of CSU in Uden has more than 22,000.

ASML stands out as the fastest-growing employer, with more than 21,000 full-time jobs in the Netherlands, up more than 76 percent in five years. Action followed with 13,401 full-time positions, up more than a third.

name: Publicis Groupe
title: Year in Review 2025: Consolidation, Chaos, and Cookies - ExchangeWire.com
description:
Omnicom and IPG: The year’s defining merger Last December’s news that Omnicom would acquire IPG sent shockwaves through Madison Avenue.
French-based Equativ sealed its long-discussed union with Sharethrough, forming one of the largest independent ad tech platforms outside the walled gardens.
Google’s rough year in court No year-in-review would be complete without Google’s legal woes, and 2025 delivered them in spades.
Judge Amit Mehta spared the browser from sale in Google’s parallel search antitrust trial, and Brinkema has signalled similar hesitation in the ad tech case.
For others, it was a fitting conclusion to a year defined by circular upheaval: consolidation without clarity, innovation without confidence, and regulation without resolve.
text:
With 2026 just days away, take a look at the major stories of 2025 - and their impact across the ad tech landscape…

Mergers old and new reshaped the agency landscape; regulators pushed back against the giants; and Google quietly admitted something few thought possible - that the cookie era might be here to stay after all.

Omnicom and IPG: The year’s defining merger

Last December’s news that Omnicom would acquire IPG sent shockwaves through Madison Avenue. The deal, worth an estimated USD$25bn, promised to create the world’s largest agency network - a marketing behemoth with combined billings dwarfing even WPP’s. Unsurprisingly, the US Federal Trade Commission (FTC) stepped in, flagging concerns that the tie-up could limit competition across media buying, creative services, and data management.

For months, the transaction hovered in limbo. But a revised framework for “cross-stack ad competition” introduced midyear gave the merger new life. By late summer, the FTC cleared the deal, followed in December by unconditional approval from the European Commission. Almost immediately, Omnicom announced a sweeping restructure: 4,000 roles set to go before year-end as it moves to consolidate overlapping units and unify its data strategy under a single global platform.

Consolidation everywhere you look

The mergers kept coming. French-based Equativ sealed its long-discussed union with Sharethrough, forming one of the largest independent ad tech platforms outside the walled gardens. The combined group now boasts significant reach across CTV, programmatic, and supply optimisation.

Meanwhile, Publicis made headlines with its acquisition of Lotame. The move adds Lotame’s data reservoir - roughly 1.6 billion user profiles - to the Groupe’s increasingly ID-driven data stack. Publicis wasted no time folding those audience graphs into its Epsilon offering, pitching enhanced precision targeting just as fragmentation across identifiers reached new highs.

The battle for Warner Bros

In media, the year’s most extraordinary rumour mill centred on Warner Bros Discovery, which officially put itself up for sale. Both Netflix and Paramount Skydance made plays - and Netflix seemed to have the agreement in place. Paramount then lobbed in a USD$108.4bn hostile bid, aiming to outmuscle Netflix’s already massive USD$72bn offer. The board, though, recommended rejecting Paramount’s offer - but few expect this story to end before 2026.

TikTok survives again - with a new flag

Across the Atlantic, political drama continued to define TikTok’s fate. In September, a newly re-elected Donald Trump signed an executive order forcing Chinese parent company ByteDance to transfer US ownership to American investors. The move, framed as a national security measure, effectively prevented a TikTok shutdown in the States - and marked the culmination of a years-long tug of war over the app’s future.

ByteDance eventually reached a binding deal with groups including Oracle, Silver Lake, and MGX. If completed in early 2026, the agreement will create a separate joint venture for TikTok’s US business, finally putting the app’s legal limbo to rest - at least for now.

Google’s rough year in court

No year-in-review would be complete without Google’s legal woes, and 2025 delivered them in spades. The search giant faced a crushing verdict in April, when Judge Leonie Brinkema ruled that it maintained two illegal monopolies across ad tech - one in publisher ad servers, another in exchange technology.

The decision unleashed fresh lawsuits from Magnite and PubMatic, both seeking damages for what they describe as years of exclusionary practices.

Yet the more draconian remedies - a forced breakup or Chrome divestiture - seem increasingly unlikely. Judge Amit Mehta spared the browser from sale in Google’s parallel search antitrust trial, and Brinkema has signalled similar hesitation in the ad tech case. Pending verdicts aside, the industry’s response has been pragmatic: frustration, but little shock. The perceived imbalance between regulators’ power and Big Tech’s legal muscle remains, for now, intact.

AI upends traffic and trust

While courts debated competition, the open web faced a different kind of existential challenge. As AI chatbots and search tools proliferated, referral traffic to publishers cratered. Appfigures and SimilarWeb both recorded steep double-digit declines in click-throughs to news sites across major markets, with much of that traffic diverted to AI-generated summaries.

Publishers responded with lawsuits, block lists, and pleas for licensing deals. Yet the scraping continued and 2025 became, by consensus, the year that open access content was effectively subsumed into large language model training data. One board member of the Independent Publishers Alliance estimated that Google’s new AI-powered search could push a third of its members into closure within a year.

What AI giveth in efficiency, it taketh away in discoverability.

The cookie that wouldn’t crumble

And finally, the year’s most unexpected twist: the third-party cookie lived to see another day. After half a decade of phased plans, pilot schemes, and developer summits, Google officially scrapped its deprecation timeline. Privacy Sandbox was quietly wound down, its core tools shuttered.

The decision, reportedly tied to both antitrust pressure and publisher backlash, sent shockwaves across the ecosystem. After years spent preparing for a “post-cookie world”, advertisers and platforms alike found themselves back where they started - albeit older, wiser, and more cynical about Google’s willingness to change its own rules.

For some, that retreat marked the end of an era. For others, it was a fitting conclusion to a year defined by circular upheaval: consolidation without clarity, innovation without confidence, and regulation without resolve.

name: Best Buy
title: I watch every tech launch event — here's what they still get wrong and what they get right
description:
In 2025, Google, Apple, Samsung, and everyone else who announced new tech products delivered beautifully curated keynotes that told us exactly what they wanted us to hear about the said devices.
On the opposite end, Meta literally winged it with live demos of their new smart glasses.
If tech companies want launch events to matter in 2026, they need to stop giving us Keynotes that could have been emails or overcomplicating them to the point where we lose interest.
Keep consumer launches and developer events separate Google's I/O and Apple's WWDC keep developer updates separate from their launch events, but they sometimes blur the line between the two.
So, for 2026, companies should totally keep the live demos.
text:
In 2025, Google, Apple, Samsung, and everyone else who announced new tech products delivered beautifully curated keynotes that told us exactly what they wanted us to hear about the said devices.

I agree that Google went above and beyond this year for its Pixel 10 launch, delivering something that felt less like a Keynote and more like a massive production hosted by Jimmy Fallon. On the opposite end, Meta literally winged it with live demos of their new smart glasses. While the demos didn't go as planned, they stayed fairly realistic, which is what we, as consumers who pay a hefty price for electronics, would appreciate seeing.

If tech companies want launch events to matter in 2026, they need to stop giving us Keynotes that could have been emails or overcomplicating them to the point where we lose interest. Instead, they need to offer more clarity and a better understanding of how an average person seeking to buy a new anything will perceive and use these products.

Here's what I'd love to see change in 2026 — and what's worth keeping.

Give it to me straight — in plain English

Too often, companies end up explaining features the way they'd talk to engineers and not, well, us. We hear about "tokens per second," model sizes, or how "Siri now has a deeper understanding of your personal context."

There's a ton of technical jargon, and not much about how those things show up in the real world. Launch events need to answer questions when explaining a new feature — It comes down to the basics: "Why would I actually need it, when would I use it, and what problem would it solve?"

If I don't understand the practicality of a new feature and how it would help me in the real world, then what's the point of having some elaborate speech about it?

Take Google's Gemini, for instance: instead of telling me it's faster, smarter, and more "multimodal," tell me whether Gemini can look at a photo I took and explain why it looks bad and how to fix it before I share it. Even Samsung and Apple end up using loads of jargon in their Keynotes.

Apple loves to show off those emotionally hitting polished stories — the Apple Watch saving a life, the iPhone shooting a fancy music video (with tons of extra gear, post-production edits, of course). Samsung often bombards viewers with so many features so quickly, with little guidance on which actually matter.

But they skip the messy part: regular people trying to use that same tech and ending up with a terrible photo, bad lighting, or just a picture that looks nothing like the ad. In 2026, I want to see companies balance those magical tales with what these features actually look like for a totally average user. Because great stories definitely make people care, but great explanations push people to buy the product.

Keep consumer launches and developer events separate

Google's I/O and Apple's WWDC keep developer updates separate from their launch events, but they sometimes blur the line between the two. For example, this year's I/O featured major product announcements, including the launch of Android 16, a demonstration of Gemini's multimodal capabilities, and a preview of a prototype of Google's XR glasses.

This mix at an event aimed just for developers is definitely cool. Google's probably trying to get more than just coders interested in I/O, but it's also leaving people confused about whether they should be glued to I/O or just watch the "Made by Google" for consumer-focused announcements. If you ask me, I'd say keep the two separate, don't overcomplicate it. That way, the audience knows what to expect at each event and won't miss anything of interest.

Keep the live demos — even if they fail

Both Google and Meta actually tried live demos in 2025, and sometimes, despite practicing it a zillion times before D-day, they don't go as planned. WiFi dropped, or connectivity lagged, leading to awkward pauses during a live show.

But that necessarily isn't failure. While people pick on these moments to criticize the company, make a ton of memes, they can also work to the company's favor. It showed us the reality that mistakes happen — especially with common issues like connectivity problems, and this to me comes across as more authentic and raw, rather than scripted videos.

It also gives companies a real-world moment to look at what works and what still needs work before a product reaches consumers.

So, for 2026, companies should totally keep the live demos. But they could try to swap out the celebrities for everyday people to make things more relevant for someone watching on their couch at home. You know, parents, students—those who don't care about the techy buzzwords but who will actually be using these cool new devices and features.

And just keep things simple, to the point, showing us how features will help normal people, rather than over-the-top shows with so much going on that people forget about it as soon as the show's over.

text:
Nvidia NVDA and Broadcom AVGO may be positioned for potential gains in 2026, Cantor Fitzgerald said Wednesday, following a period of recent weakness in semiconductor stocks.

Analyst C.J. Muse noted that AI-related stocks have faced pressure since early November amid broader market caution and concerns over an AI valuation bubble. Muse said these concerns might be overstated, given growing demand tied to AI infrastructure.

Nvidia shares are trading at roughly 16 times Cantor's earnings estimates. The rollout of next-generation hardware, the Rubin GPU architecture and the custom Vera CPU, which together form the Vera Rubin platform, is expected to support massive-context AI workloads and data center growth.

Broadcom is valued around 26 times Cantor's earnings estimates. Muse highlighted the company's networking business and its role in supporting Google GOOG tensor processing units, which could further benefit from AI-driven infrastructure spending.

The firm reiterated Nvidia and Broadcom as top picks for 2026, suggesting investors consider establishing positions ahead of anticipated AI-related growth, according to a Wednesday press release.

description:
NVIDIA (NVDA) edged up 1.0% to close at $190.53 on news of a $20 billion licensing deal with AI chip startup Groq.
The Groq licensing agreement is a significant strategic move, reinforcing NVIDIA’s dominance in the AI inference market.
By acquiring talent and access to Groq’s high-performance technology, NVIDIA is proactively neutralizing a potential competitor and widening its competitive moat.
Trade Mechanics & Money Flow Trade Mechanics: What Happened?
Understanding trade mechanics, money flow, and price behavior can give you and edge.
text:
NVIDIA (NVDA) edged up 1.0% to close at $190.53 on news of a $20 billion licensing deal with AI chip startup Groq. The move was orderly on below-average holiday volume, extending a recent winning streak. But with the stock already up over 11% in the prior six sessions, is this merely a tactical news-driven pop or the start of a new leg higher into year-end?

The Groq licensing agreement is a significant strategic move, reinforcing NVIDIA’s dominance in the AI inference market. By acquiring talent and access to Groq’s high-performance technology, NVIDIA is proactively neutralizing a potential competitor and widening its competitive moat.

NVIDIA will pay $20 billion to license Groq’s AI inference technology and hire key personnel.

The deal integrates Groq’s expertise in Language Processing Units (LPUs), enhancing NVDA’s capabilities.

This move is seen as a defensive strategy to address threats from specialized ASIC chip manufacturers.

But here is the interesting part. You are reading about this 1.0% move after it happened. The market has already priced in the news. To catch the next winner before the headlines, you need predictive signals, not notifications. High Quality Portfolio has flagged 5 new opportunities that haven not surged yet.

Trade Mechanics & Money Flow

Trade Mechanics: What Happened?

The trading mechanics on December 26th suggest a quiet, holiday-thinned market, with institutional players making targeted bets rather than a broad retail chase. The relatively low volume indicates a lack of aggressive, widespread participation, typical for the period between Christmas and New Year’s.

Trading volume was subdued at approximately 137-139 million shares, well below the daily average.

Options activity shows strong bullish sentiment, with significant open interest in calls at the $195 and $200 strike prices.

A large block trade of 26,000 calls expiring in September 2025 suggests institutional conviction in long-term upside.

How Is The Money Flowing?

The footprint of this move appears to be primarily institutional. The subdued volume combined with large, strategic options trades points towards smart money positioning for future growth rather than a retail-driven frenzy.

The quiet nature of the 1.0% move on low volume is characteristic of institutional accumulation.

Retail participation was noted, but the significant block trades in the options market indicate a larger institutional hand.

The stock closed near the psychologically important $190 level, setting up a potential test of higher resistance.

What Next?

A decisive break above this level, particularly on increasing volume, would signal a continuation of the uptrend, likely forcing options market makers to hedge their positions and potentially creating a gamma squeeze that could accelerate the move higher.

name: Delta Airlines
title: American Airlines Reacts To 109 Holiday Flight Cancellations With A New Solution At Its Busiest Hub
description:
Meanwhile, on Friday, December 26, American Airlines was forced to cancel 109 flights, one of the highest numbers of cancellations, according to FlightAware.
American Airlines Reacts To 109 Cancellations With A New Flight Schedule On Friday, December 26, American Airlines announced significant changes at its largest and busiest hub, Dallas-Fort Worth International Airport.
American Airlines, United Airlines, and Southwest only had to cancel 3% of their scheduled departures.
American Airlines Is Focusing On Better Connections And Airport Experience Apart from the new schedule, American Airlines has also announced a few other changes to make connections easier and improve the airport experience for travelers.
The press release also reminded passengers that American Airlines is investing in several projects at DFW airport.
text:
This holiday season has been particularly stressful for those planning to catch a flight. A major winter storm, Storm Devin, hit many parts of the Northeast and Midwest immediately after Christmas, leading to thousands of cancellations nationwide — although many U.S. airlines reacted to the storm in the best way possible for passengers.

Meanwhile, on Friday, December 26, American Airlines was forced to cancel 109 flights, one of the highest numbers of cancellations, according to FlightAware. This was in part due to its high number of departures compared to other carriers.

American Airlines has since issued a press release announcing a new flight schedule for Dallas-Fort Worth International Airport (DFW), which will provide “greater resilience and less adverse impact” in the event of bad weather. Here's a closer look at this new plan and how it will affect passengers.

American Airlines Reacts To 109 Cancellations With A New Flight Schedule

On Friday, December 26, American Airlines announced significant changes at its largest and busiest hub, Dallas-Fort Worth International Airport. The carrier plans to invest millions of dollars to offer a smoother airport experience, enhance connections for travelers on layovers, and improve resilience in case of weather disruptions.

For years, American Airlines’ schedule at its Dallas hub has been divided into nine banks, a term referring to a group of flights operating roughly at the same time. Beginning in April, the airline will introduce a 13-bank structure, adding new time options. Changes to the schedule will become visible today, Saturday, December 27.

What does this mean for passengers?

American Airlines customers will be able to choose from more departures during "highly desired" time windows, as well as fewer early-morning flights. According to the carrier, this is "especially good news for customers making morning connections through DFW."

These changes will also help the airline recover better when bad weather hits.

“No other airline recovers from bad weather and irregular operations better than American, and the airline has demonstrated that time and time again," the company's press release states.

Now, the airline has stated that its new schedule structure will ensure it will "recover even quicker and get customers on their way as soon as the weather clears." American Airlines is also investing millions of dollars in remote deplaning capability, which will help the carrier divert fewer flights away from DFW.

American Airlines Canceled 3% Of Its Flights On Boxing Day

On Boxing Day, Friday, December 26, New York, along with many parts of the Northeast and Midwest, was hit by a heavy winter storm, leading to hundreds of flight cancellations. According to the latest advisory from the National Weather Service, published at 5:20 a.m. EST on Saturday, December 27, a winter storm warning will remain in effect until 10 a.m.

Delta Air Lines was the U.S. carrier with the most cancellations on Friday, with 254 flights canceled, representing about 7% of its scheduled departures for the day. JetBlue followed it with 232 cancellations, representing 23% of its total flights.

American Airlines, United Airlines, and Southwest only had to cancel 3% of their scheduled departures. The airports that were hit hardest were John F. Kennedy International Airport (JFK) and Newark Liberty International Airport (EWR), which reported 159 and 107 cancellations, respectively.

At the moment, it seems that travel disruptions will continue today. Flight Radar reports 131 cancellations at JFK, 85 at La Guardia Airport (LGA), and 70 at Newark Liberty (EWR). For now, American Airlines has been forced to cancel 1% of its departures, for a total of 57 flights, while JetBlue is at the top with 159 cancellations. However, American, along with United Airlines and JetBlue, have responded in kind to passengers amid all the Storm Devin cancellations; the three told Reuters they have waived change and re-booking fees.

According to American Airlines’ press release, bad weather is a serious issue for the carrier, especially at DFW, where thunderstorms have recently forced the entire airport to pause. Apart from the new flight schedule at DFW, the carrier is also investing in a better airport experience for its customers and smoother connections.

American Airlines Is Focusing On Better Connections And Airport Experience

Apart from the new schedule, American Airlines has also announced a few other changes to make connections easier and improve the airport experience for travelers. The new schedule is now reducing extremely short layovers, leading to a less stressful travel experience.

In addition, the company launched an AI tool at DFW Airport in May 2025. This helps connecting passengers get to their second flight by ensuring pilots wait for them in case of delays, when possible. The company has recently announced it will now use this technology in five additional airports.

The press release also reminded passengers that American Airlines is investing in several projects at DFW airport. These include modernizing its airport facilities and adding extra piers, resulting in 31 new gates by 2030.

While American Airlines claims to be the best U.S. carrier at handling flight disruptions caused by bad weather, on December 27, it reported the same cancellation rate as United Airlines and Southwest Airlines. Only time will tell whether this new schedule will make a real difference.

name: Walmart
title: Kurtz, Wesley C - RETAIL THEFT PACC 3929 A1 | Ephrata Police Department
description:
On Monday, December 8, 2025, at approximately 1546 hours, the Ephrata Police Department was dispatched to Walmart, 890 E. Main St., Ephrata township for a shoplifter in custody.
Walmart loss prevention had a male in custody, later identified as Wesley Kurtz, 30, of Denver for taking $52.34 worth of merchandise.
Kurtz walked past all points of sale without attempting to pay for the items.
Kurtz was arrested and transported to the Ephrata Police Department to be processed.
Kurtz was issued a summary non-traffic citation for Retail Theft.
text: On Monday, December 8, 2025, at approximately 1546 hours, the Ephrata Police Department was dispatched to Walmart, 890 E. Main St., Ephrata township for a shoplifter in custody. Walmart loss prevention had a male in custody, later identified as Wesley Kurtz, 30, of Denver for taking $52.34 worth of merchandise. Kurtz walked past all points of sale without attempting to pay for the items. Kurtz was arrested and transported to the Ephrata Police Department to be processed. Kurtz was issued a summary non-traffic citation for Retail Theft. Kurtz is presumed innocent.

name: Carrier
title: Ethiopian Airlines Introduces Full Strip-and-Paint Process for Airbus A350-900 Fleet
description:
Ethiopian Airlines Pioneers Full Strip-and-Paint Process for Airbus A350-900 Fleet Ethiopian Airlines has marked a significant milestone by completing Africa’s first full strip-and-paint process on its Airbus A350-900 fleet, setting a new standard in aircraft maintenance on the continent.
The airline’s technical team ensured that the process adhered to stringent international standards, underscoring Ethiopian Airlines’ unwavering commitment to safety and operational excellence.
The Airbus A350-900, renowned for its fuel efficiency and cutting-edge technology, forms a critical component of the airline’s long-haul fleet.
While Ethiopian Airlines’ current focus remains on the A350-900, the broader concerns surrounding Airbus products may prompt competitors and regulators to intensify their examination of fleet maintenance practices.
Ethiopian Airlines’ successful execution of the full strip-and-paint process on both its Boeing 787 and Airbus A350-900 fleets places it among a select group of global carriers capable of conducting such advanced maintenance in-house.
text:
Ethiopian Airlines Pioneers Full Strip-and-Paint Process for Airbus A350-900 Fleet

Ethiopian Airlines has marked a significant milestone by completing Africa’s first full strip-and-paint process on its Airbus A350-900 fleet, setting a new standard in aircraft maintenance on the continent. This achievement highlights the airline’s advanced maintenance, repair, and overhaul (MRO) capabilities, reinforcing its leadership in operational efficiency and fleet durability.

Advancing Maintenance Capabilities

The full strip-and-paint procedure involves the meticulous removal of all existing paint layers, followed by a comprehensive repainting of the aircraft. This complex process is essential for preserving the structural integrity of the aircraft, enhancing its aesthetic appeal, and improving fuel efficiency by reducing aerodynamic drag. By investing in the necessary technology and infrastructure to perform such high-level maintenance internally, Ethiopian Airlines has significantly reduced its dependence on external service providers, thereby strengthening its competitive position within the aviation sector.

The airline’s technical team ensured that the process adhered to stringent international standards, underscoring Ethiopian Airlines’ unwavering commitment to safety and operational excellence. The Airbus A350-900, renowned for its fuel efficiency and cutting-edge technology, forms a critical component of the airline’s long-haul fleet. Maintaining these aircraft in optimal condition is vital to delivering a safe and comfortable experience for passengers.

Industry Context and Strategic Implications

This development occurs amid heightened industry scrutiny over quality and software issues affecting Airbus’s A320 family. While Ethiopian Airlines’ current focus remains on the A350-900, the broader concerns surrounding Airbus products may prompt competitors and regulators to intensify their examination of fleet maintenance practices. Such scrutiny could influence investor confidence, as apprehensions about potential operational disruptions and the impact on Airbus’s reputation may affect purchasing decisions and fleet management strategies across the global aviation industry.

Ethiopian Airlines’ successful execution of the full strip-and-paint process on both its Boeing 787 and Airbus A350-900 fleets places it among a select group of global carriers capable of conducting such advanced maintenance in-house. This strategic initiative aligns with the airline’s broader vision to expand its MRO capabilities, fostering greater self-sufficiency and resilience in an increasingly competitive market.

As Ethiopian Airlines continues to set new benchmarks in African aviation, its dedication to technical excellence and fleet reliability establishes a standard that resonates beyond the continent, influencing the global aviation landscape.

name: Best Buy
title: Returning gifts? Some stores may charge a fee for returns | king5.com
description:
But as shoppers head back to stores, they may find that some stores charge fees for returns.
Nordstrom and other department stores also do free returns, especially when done in person.
JCPenney charges an $8 fee for online returns by mail.
Macy's waives its online return fee for Star Rewards members.
Best Buy has a $45 return fee for products that require activation, such as smartphones and tablets.
text:
WASHINGTON — With Christmas in the rearview mirror, shoppers are returning to stores — not to buy, but to bring items back.

The last week of December is infamously known for a spike in returns, with one out of every eight returns in the 2024 holiday season taking place between Dec. 26 and Dec. 31, according to Adobe Analytics. This year, the trend is expected to continue.

Between Dec. 26 and Dec. 31, returns are expected to rise by 25% to 35% compared with returns between Nov. 1 and Dec. 12, Adobe said, and it expects returns to remain elevated through the first two weeks of January, up 8% to 15%.

According to a report from the National Retail Federation, about 19% of online sales are expected to be returned in 2025.

But as shoppers head back to stores, they may find that some stores charge fees for returns.

Gift returns: Can I return items for free?

Most retailers, such as Amazon, Target and Walmart, have free returns for most items. For the holiday season, many of these retailers have an extended return window that expires in January.

Nordstrom and other department stores also do free returns, especially when done in person.

Return policies have gotten much tighter in recent years, with Marshalls and T.J. Maxx charging a fee for returns not made in person. T.J. Maxx and Marshalls, owned by TJX, charge a $11.99 fee for mail returns.

Clothing stores such as Abercrombie & Fitch, Urban Outfitters, Zara and others charge a fee, ranging from around $5 to $7, for items returned by mail.

JCPenney charges an $8 fee for online returns by mail. Macy's waives its online return fee for Star Rewards members. For non-members, a $9.99 return shipping fee plus tax, where applicable, will be deducted from the refund.

Best Buy has a $45 return fee for products that require activation, such as smartphones and tablets. Additionally, a 15% "restocking fee" will be charged for items such as drones and digital cameras.

name: Nvidia
title: Scoop: Nvidia deal a big win for Groq employees and investors - Axios
description:
Why it matters: Social media has been full of questions about what the unusual arrangement means for Groq employees — both those heading to Nvidia and those staying put.
Catch up quick: Groq and Nvidia on Wednesday announced a "non-exclusive licensing agreement," with media reports accurately pegging the deal value at around $20 billion.
Behind the scenes: Most Groq shareholders will receive per-share distributions tied to the $20 billion valuation, according to sources.
Around 90% of Groq employees are said to be joining Nvidia, and they will be paid cash for all vested shares.
Remaining Groq employees will also be paid for vested shares, plus will receive a package that includes economic participation in the ongoing company.
text:
Shareholders in Groq, a hot AI chipmaking startup, will receive handsome payouts from the company's $20 billion deal with Nvidia, even though no equity is changing hands, Axios has learned from sources close to the deal.

Why it matters: Social media has been full of questions about what the unusual arrangement means for Groq employees — both those heading to Nvidia and those staying put.

Catch up quick: Groq and Nvidia on Wednesday announced a "non-exclusive licensing agreement," with media reports accurately pegging the deal value at around $20 billion.

The companies said that Groq CEO Jonathan Ross and president Sunny Madra would join Nvidia, while Groq would continue to operate as a standalone company led by new CEO Simon Edwards (who had been CFO).

It's an unusual structure, but the latest in a recent spate of Big AI deals that seem designed to avoid tripping antitrust wires.

Behind the scenes: Most Groq shareholders will receive per-share distributions tied to the $20 billion valuation, according to sources.

Around 85% will be paid up-front, while another 10% is paid midyear 2026 and the remainder at the end of 2026.

Around 90% of Groq employees are said to be joining Nvidia, and they will be paid cash for all vested shares. Their unvested shares will be paid out at the $20 billion valuation, but via Nvidia stock that vests on a schedule.

There are also around 50 members of that group whose entire stock packages are being accelerated and paid out in cash.

Remaining Groq employees will also be paid for vested shares, plus will receive a package that includes economic participation in the ongoing company.

Any Groq employee — staying or leaving — with the company for less than one year will have their vesting cliff dropped, so they can get some up-front liquidity.

By the numbers: Groq had raised around $3.3 billion in venture capital funding since its 2016 founding, including a $750 million infusion this past fall at nearly a $7 billion post-money valuation.

Backers include Social Capital, BlackRock, Neuberger Berman, Deutsche Telekom Capital Partners, Samsung, 1789 Capital, Cisco, D1, Cleo Capital, Altimeter, Firestreak Ventures, Conversion Capital and Modi Venture.

The company has never done a secondary tender for either employees or investors.

The bottom line: Everyone gets paid. A lot.
